metadata.case_name: Raja Rajinder Chand v. Defendants (Adna Maliks)

facts.text: Plaintiff Raja Rajinder Chand, superior landlord (alamalik) of Nadaun Jagir in Kangra district, brought six suits in Subordinate Judge Kangra for declaration of ownership of all pine (chil-pinus longifolia) trees on defendants' lands, permanent injunction against interference, and damages for tapping from March 24, 1940.
Defendants, adna maliks (inferior landlords), pleaded ownership and possession of lands and trees thereon; plaintiff had no right and never exercised possession.
Subordinate Judge held plaintiff failed to prove ownership, suits barred by limitation, dismissed suits (small damages if ownership proved).
District Judge Hoshiarpur reversed on ownership and limitation, accepted damages finding, allowed appeals, granted declaration, injunction, damages in four suits.
Punjab High Court reversed District Judge on ownership (agreed with Subordinate Judge), agreed on limitation, allowed appeals, dismissed suits. Gave certificate under CPC ss. 109, 110.
Suit lands in Badhog and Jasai tappas within Nadaun Jagir, Kangra district; proprietary and cultivated lands of adna maliks.
Last independent ruler of Kangra: Raja Sansar Chand (died 1824), Katoch Rajput; legitimate son Anirudh Chand, illegitimate son Jodhbir Chand (Gaddi tribe).
Kangra conquered by Sikhs under Ranjit Singh; Jodhbir Chand created Raja, granted Nadaun Jagir; Anirudh Chand fled to British territory.
Raja Rajinder Chand is direct lineal descendant of Raja Jodhbir Chand (fourth in descent).

British occupation after Sikh wars (1846, 1848); Sanad to Jodhbir Chand dated October 11, 1848, renewing 1846 Sanad; granted Jagir (tappas, villages, jama Rs. 26,270/10/3) in perpetuity to male legitimate descendants, subject to conditions (no criminal jurisdiction, revenue only per British rules, etc.).

Settlements: Barnes (1850-52, no Nadaun ops); Lyall (1865-72, no Nadaun); O'Brien/Anderson (1892-93 Wajib-ul-arz Ex.P-5: pine trees Government right); Anderson (1899-1900 Ex.P-6: chil trees property of Raja); Middleton/Shuttleworth (1910-15 Ex.P-4: pine trees Raja's except certain).
Ala-malik (superior owner/talukdar), adna-malik (inferior owner); proprietary profits shared.
Ex.P-2 (1886): Adna maliks complained Rajas men cut chil trees on their lands.
Jamabandis (Exs.D-7, D-8) show no restriction on adna maliks' tree rights.
Wajib-ul-arz para 12 (Ex.D-2): Raja gets 15% talukdari dues on net revenue to compensate all dues.
Prior judgments (Exs.P-9,P-7,P-8,P-4): Recognized Raja's rights but based on Wajib-ul-arz, no res judicata.
No documents of Raja's income from trees produced.

legal_issues.text: Whether all pine trees standing on suit lands (proprietary/cultivated lands of adna maliks) are property of plaintiff ala malik.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ownership based on: (1) Ancestors (independent Kangra rulers) owned land/trees, granted land to adna maliks' ancestors retaining pine trees; (2) Post-conquest, British rights assigned to Jodhbir Chand via Sanad; (3) Wajib-ul-arz entries (1892-93,1899-1900,1910-15) vouchsafed right, recognized in judicial decisions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kangra Gazetteer, Settlement Reports, Sanad 1848, Wajib-ul-arz

respondent_arguments.text: Defendants own lands/trees in possession; plaintiff has no right, never exercised possession. Wajib-ul-arz entries relate to waste/reclaimed lands only, not proprietary/cultivated; no surrender by Government.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected ground 1: Jodhbir Chand illegitimate, no sovereign rights post-Sikh annexation; grantee under Ranjit Singh/British, not successor to Sansar Chand.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sovereign rights passed to Sikhs then British; distinction between sovereign and grantee rights.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected ground 2: Sanad 1848 grants land revenue (jama) only, per British rules; no mention of trees; construed favourably for sovereign.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Condition 2 limits to revenue; jama excludes grazing/excise; no sovereign rights granted.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected ground 3: Wajib-ul-arz entries (Exs.P-4,5,6) not evidence of custom/surrender of sovereign right; confuse waste/proprietary lands; no unambiguous grant; revenue officers' views not binding; Jamabandis silent; endorsement not admission.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wajib-ul-arz records customs, not creates titles; presumption displaced; no docs of surrender.

court_reasoning.text: Oral evidence unreliable; prior judgments based on same entries, no res judicata.

holdings.text: Appellant failed to establish ownership right to pine trees on proprietary/cultivated lands of adna maliks.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State: rights only as recognized by new sovereign.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur
precedents_cited.relevance: Revenue authorities' views on grant construction not binding on civil courts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Land-Revenue Act, 1887
statutes_cited.relevance: Wajib-ul-arz part of record-of-rights; entries presumed true.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the six appeals, upholding Punjab High Court dismissal of suits; appellant failed to prove ownership of pine trees; no order as to costs in any court due to confusion from Wajib-ul-arz entries.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs in High Court or courts below.

key_quotes.text: "When a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time that is an act of State... Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal courts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why no sovereign rights passed to grantee Jodhbir Chand.

key_quotes.text: "The Wajib-ul-arz, though it does not create a title, gives rise to a presumption in its support which prevails unless the presumption is properly displaced."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Legal effect of Wajib-ul-arz entries; presumption held displaced.

key_quotes.text: "grants made by the Sovereign are to be construed most favourably for the Sovereign."
key_quotes.speaker: court
